Pachieke, in the mean time, happening to ride that way, sees the plain void of horses, and quickly suspecting the truth of the matter, from the footsteps of the plundering Riikahes, flies to Debayakaikin, laments the loss of the horses, asks for assist- ance, and expresses great hopes of being able to pursue and chastise the enemy. Without delay, all the neighbouring Abipones, vvith their Cacique Debayakaikin, eagerly pursue Ychoalay, whom, having overtaken, they challenge to the fight. As usual, the whole of the infantry joined battle. Both sides fought furiously for some time, till victory declared in favour of the Riikahes: for Debayakaikin, the Hector of his people, was slain with a spear by Ychoalay3 many of his followers received the same fate from those of his adversary, and indeed, accord- ing to common report, not one of the enemy would have escaped alive, had not the conque- ror prevented his soldiers from slaying the rest, declaring that he thought no blame attached to the common herd of Indians, who had only taken up arms 111 obedience to their leader.
